awd_titl_txt: Hybrid mathematical modeling for cell fate determination in clustered cell migration
awd_abstract_narration:
Fate of the cell, arguably the most basic building block of life, is guided by many things, internal  drive and external influences among them.  As cells grow in community, differences arise and roles  are established.  How are different roles established?  What influences are paramount in deciding?  What is the interplay of roles and influences that produces the growing pattern, in time and space?  Mathematics seeks to discover patterns and applying mathematical modeling to cells that are fated to migrate and travel in clusters will describe the balance between intrinsic and extrinsic signals. In domains that are challenging to visualize in experiments and that change over time, theory and computation can guide discovery of the principles at work determining cell fate and decision-making, ultimately to facilitate normal development and to hinder malignant growth.  This research will also train diverse researchers to fulfill their roles in scientific discovery.
 
Successful cell migration is critical for human development, immune response, and advancement of some diseases, but much remains unknown. In particular, there are many gaps in our knowledge of how cells navigate in vivo through complex tissue environments over time. This project will leverage  mathematical modeling and the simple, genetically tractable, Drosophila ovary to address open  questions about how cells acquire motility, coordinate behaviors with neighboring cells, and move  within an organ.  In many cases communication about these behaviors between cells must occur  through the extracellular space. It is unclear how extracellular signaling molecules, such as chemoattractants and cytokines, are distributed in tissues, and how spatially dependent differences in concentration may affect signaling. For example, extracellular signal, such Unpaired (UPD), can interact with the transmembrane Janus Kinase (JAK) to activate the Signal Transducer and Activator of Transcription (STAT) responsible for the cell fate motility decision. The hypothesis is that the heteromorphic extracellular domain impacts signal distribution and motile cell behaviors, which can be revealed through a hybrid agent-based model coupled to a reaction-diffusion model of extracellular signal converted to intracellular signalling and movement.  Based on imaging data, we will accurately model heterogeneity in tissue structure and examine the impact of this physical constraint on molecular diffusion and signaling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Successful cell migration is critical for human development and immune response, and can advance some diseases, but much remains unknown. In particular, there are many gaps in our knowledge of how cells navigate in vivo through complex tissue environments over time to end up where they are needed. The results from this award leveraged mathematical modeling and the simple, genetically tractable, fruit fly ovary to address open questions about how cells acquire motility, coordinate behaviors with neighboring cells, and move within an organ.

In many cases, communication about these behaviors between cells must occur through the space between cells. It is unclear how the distribution of chemical signaling molecules, such as chemoattractants, in this space may affect communication about, for example, whether a cell will move or stay put.

We tested the hypothesis that the variable space between cells impacts signal distribution and the directive for cells to move. Results can be revealed through a mathematical model made up of points on the boundaries of cells (our “agent-based model”) interacting with one another following physical laws.  We then combined this model, using those points to make boundaries, with a model for the movement and final distribution of the signaling molecules. 

Specifically, we were able to accomplish several goals along this pathway

1)    We were able to define and test a mathematical model for the stay-or-go fate a cell experiences based on a particular chemical signaling pathway, a pathway that also is present in human cells.

2)    We were able to make an agent-based model in two dimensions and find a balance of parameters that reproduces the same type of behavior as when clusters of cells are migrating.

3)    We were able to convert a detailed image set from an experiment that labeled all of the cell membranes within a three-dimensional tissue structure into a data file that we can import into the computer for simulation.

4)    We were able, with this detailed cell geometry even in three dimensions, predict the distribution of signaling molecules in the space between cells (flatter in larger spaces), suggest the path for clusters of cells to move along, and predict how their speed is impacted (slower in larger spaces) due to signal distribution (and not just because of other cells being in the way).

5)    We were able to confirm this behavior both in experiments and in a mathematical model along the main migration pathway, getting at the comparison between smaller and larger spaces between cells.  One important prediction is that the sensing mechanism on cells, receptors, become overwhelmed by signal, which slows movement with higher levels of signal.  This was supported by biology experiments where even more signal was added via genetic modification and the cluster was even slower, though with similar relative slowdowns in the larger spaces.

Research into the development of an integrated model combining cellular migration and its surrounding chemical and physical environment is applicable to a broad range of biophysical situations. These advances will aid in addressing both theoretical and concrete scientific questions.

We have been able to and will continue to alert colleagues to our progress through several presentations and publications by the PI and coPI as well as by our many graduate and undergraduate students.  We were able to train up to 11 students with 7 of those female in STEM, develop curriculum, and overall broaden the landscape for interdisciplinary research, which will be critical for tackling cutting edge problems in biology and mathematics.

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2024
Modified by: Bradford E Peercy

Successful cell migration is critical for human development and immune response, and can advance some diseases, but much remains unknown. In particular, there are many gaps in our knowledge of how cells navigate in vivo through complex tissue environments over time to end up where they are needed. The results from this award leveraged mathematical modeling and the simple, genetically tractable, fruit fly ovary to address open questions about how cells acquire motility, coordinate behaviors with neighboring cells, and move within an organ.


In many cases, communication about these behaviors between cells must occur through the space between cells. It is unclear how the distribution of chemical signaling molecules, such as chemoattractants, in this space may affect communication about, for example, whether a cell will move or stay put.


We tested the hypothesis that the variable space between cells impacts signal distribution and the directive for cells to move. Results can be revealed through a mathematical model made up of points on the boundaries of cells (our agent-based model) interacting with one another following physical laws. We then combined this model, using those points to make boundaries, with a model for the movement and final distribution of the signaling molecules.


Specifically, we were able to accomplish several goals along this pathway


1) We were able to define and test a mathematical model for the stay-or-go fate a cell experiences based on a particular chemical signaling pathway, a pathway that also is present in human cells.

5) We were able to confirm this behavior both in experiments and in a mathematical model along the main migration pathway, getting at the comparison between smaller and larger spaces between cells. One important prediction is that the sensing mechanism on cells, receptors, become overwhelmed by signal, which slows movement with higher levels of signal. This was supported by biology experiments where even more signal was added via genetic modification and the cluster was even slower, though with similar relative slowdowns in the larger spaces.


Research into the development of an integrated model combining cellular migration and its surrounding chemical and physical environment is applicable to a broad range of biophysical situations. These advances will aid in addressing both theoretical and concrete scientific questions.


We have been able to and will continue to alert colleagues to our progress through several presentations and publications by the PI and coPI as well as by our many graduate and undergraduate students. We were able to train up to 11 students with 7 of those female in STEM, develop curriculum, and overall broaden the landscape for interdisciplinary research, which will be critical for tackling cutting edge problems in biology and mathematics.
